member.name: T:ExtinguishableFire
member.summary: This simulate an extinguishable fire,

member.name: T:ParticleCollision
member.summary: This script demonstrate how to use the particle system collision callback. The sample using it is the "Extinguish" prefab. It use a second, non displayed particle system to lighten the load of collision detection.

member.name: F:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.Magnitude
member.summary: The intensity of the shake. It is recommended that you use ScaleMagnitude to alter the magnitude of a shake.

member.name: F:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.Roughness
member.summary: Roughness of the shake. It is recommended that you use ScaleRoughness to alter the roughness of a shake.

member.name: F:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.PositionInfluence
member.summary: How much influence this shake has over the local position axes of the camera.

member.name: F:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.RotationInfluence
member.summary: How much influence this shake has over the local rotation axes of the camera.

member.name: F:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.DeleteOnInactive
member.summary: Should this shake be removed from the CameraShakeInstance list when not active?

member.name: M:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Will create a new instance that will shake once and fade over the given number of seconds.
member.param: The intensity of the shake.
How long, in seconds, to fade out the shake.
Roughness of the shake. Lower values are smoother, higher values are more jarring.

member.name: M:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.#ctor(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Will create a new instance that will start a sustained shake.
member.param: The intensity of the shake.
Roughness of the shake. Lower values are smoother, higher values are more jarring.

member.name: M:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.StartFadeOut(System.Single)
member.summary: Starts a fade out over the given number of seconds.
member.param: The duration, in seconds, of the fade out.

member.name: M:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.StartFadeIn(System.Single)
member.summary: Starts a fade in over the given number of seconds.
member.param: The duration, in seconds, of the fade in.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.ScaleRoughness
member.summary: Scales this shake's roughness while preserving the initial Roughness.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.ScaleMagnitude
member.summary: Scales this shake's magnitude while preserving the initial Magnitude.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.NormalizedFadeTime
member.summary: A normalized value (about 0 to about 1) that represents the current level of intensity.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakeInstance.CurrentState
member.summary: Gets the current state of the shake.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.Bump
member.summary: [One-Shot] A high magnitude, short, yet smooth shake.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.Explosion
member.summary: [One-Shot] An intense and rough shake.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.Earthquake
member.summary: [Sustained] A continuous, rough shake.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.BadTrip
member.summary: [Sustained] A bizarre shake with a very high magnitude and low roughness.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.HandheldCamera
member.summary: [Sustained] A subtle, slow shake.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.Vibration
member.summary: [Sustained] A very rough, yet low magnitude shake.

member.name: P:EZCameraShake.CameraShakePresets.RoughDriving
member.summary: [Sustained] A slightly rough, medium magnitude shake.

members.member: Class for representing a Bezier path, and methods for getting suitable points to draw the curve with line segments.
Constructs a new empty Bezier curve. Use one of these methods to add points: SetControlPoints, Interpolate, SamplePoints.
Sets the control points of this Bezier path. Points 0-3 forms the first Bezier curve, points 3-6 forms the second curve, etc.
Returns the control points for this Bezier curve.
Calculates a Bezier interpolated path for the given points.
Sample the given points as a Bezier path.
Gets the drawing points. This implementation simply calculates a certain number of points per curve.

Gets the drawing points. This implementation simply calculates a certain number of points per curve.
This is a lsightly different inplementation from the one above.
This gets the drawing points of a bezier curve, using recursive division, which results in less points for the same accuracy as the above implementation.
Caluclates a point on the Bezier curve represented with the four controlpoints given.

members.member: A concrete subclass of the Unity UI `Graphic` class that just skips drawing. Useful for providing a raycast target without actually drawing anything.
Probably not necessary since the chain of calls `Rebuild()`->`UpdateGeometry()`->`DoMeshGeneration()`->`OnPopulateMesh()` won't happen; so here really just as a fail-safe.

member.name: T:UnityEngine.UI.Extensions.UI_InfiniteScroll
member.summary:
Infinite scroll view with automatic configuration
Fields - InitByUSer - in case your scrollrect is populated from code, you can explicitly Initialize the infinite scroll after your scroll is ready by callin Init() method
Notes - doesn't work in both vertical and horizontal orientation at the same time. - in order to work it disables layout components and size fitter if present(automatically)

member.name: T:UnityEngine.UI.Extensions.UI_ScrollRectOcclusion
member.summary:
ScrollRectOcclusion - disables the objects outside of the scrollrect viewport. Useful for scrolls with lots of content, reduces geometry and drawcalls (if content is not batched)
Fields - InitByUSer - in case your scrollrect is populated from code, you can explicitly Initialize the infinite scroll after your scroll is ready by calling Init() method
Notes - In some cases it might create a bit of spikes, especially if you have lots of UI.Text objects in the child's. In that case consider to Add CanvasGroup to your child's and instead of calling setActive on game object change CanvasGroup.alpha value. At 0 it is not being rendered hence will also optimize the performance. - works for both vertical and horizontal scrolls, even at the same time (grid layout) - in order to work it disables layout components and size fitter if present (automatically)

member.name: T:UnityEngine.UI.Extensions.UI_TweenScale
member.summary:
Dynamic scalling of text or image (including button) based on curves
Fields - animCurve - animation curve for scale (if isUniform set to false, will apply only to X scale) - speed - animation speed - isLoop - animation will play infinitely (in order to make it work set your animation curve to loop) - playAtAwake - starts automatically with script becoming active. Otherwise you need to call Play() method. - isUniform - if false animCurve will modify object X scale and animCurveY - Y scale.
Notes - If you want to stop the animation call the ResetTween() method. - In some cases it can create spikes due to redrawing on change, it is recommended to use it on simple objects in separated canvases to avoid redrawing full canvas. - If you want to scale object only in 1 axis select non unifor and use linear curve from 1 to 1 to lock the scale.
